page.title: 08DRAINAGE OF THE FENS
page.content: In the early days, the{fens}were wild and windswept,with some{farming}but a lot more{wildfowling.}Newton's most famous family from the past, the {Colviles,}helped to re-claim the area from the sea. Sir Geoffrey was the first Colvile to be appointed as a commissioner of the sewers in 1314. His responsibility was to continue the drainage work that nature had begun by providing deep rivers. Sir John Colvile, who fought at the Battle of Crecy, also became a commissioner.In 1335 he had to make some hasty repairs to the sea banks.Richard Colvile, Simon Wood and others employed Henry Dereham of London to drain their lands so that a depth of one foot was dry. In return for this work, Dereham was awarded two-fifths of the land.
